Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff did not secure doors properly, allowing youth into areas
where they are not allowed access.
Investigation The Complainant was contacted over email on 07/05/2024 and
no additional information was provided.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed during a face-to-face,
unannounced visit to the facility on 07/08/2024. She recalled her
review of the incident in question, which involved a youth walking
into the control room behind a staff member where he was not
allowed. The Chief Administrator stated there is not a formal
policy regarding the locking of doors such as the control rooms
within the units, but as a secure facility many doors automatically
lock, and staff are trained to ensure they do. She also stated it is
common for staff to not attempt to enter a control room within a
unit if there is any concern over youth behavior or escalation.
Youth A was interviewed during a face-to-face, unannounced visit
to the facility on 07/08/2024. He recalled the incident where he
was able to get into the control room of the unit. Youth A stated
Staff 1 “did her job” and that he was just able to get in to the
control room. He stated that, after being in the control room, he
was able to get out of the unit and the incident escalated to the
point of him being restrained by staff. Youth A was not sure how
he was able to get out of the side door of the unit. Youth A stated
the restraint itself was not of concern to him. While inside the
control room, Youth A stated nothing significant occurred. He
recalled Staff 1 being in there with him and she told him to get out
of the room repeatedly. He also recalled Staff 1 calling for
security assistance at that time before he ran out of the room.
Youth A stated there were no other staff within the unit at the time.
2

Youth A described the control room within the units as generally
closed, and staff that enter and exit are often careful to have the
door shut behind them. He also stated there is a light above the
door that flashes red when it is open.
Youth B was interviewed during a face-to-face, announced visit to
the facility on 07/11/2024. He stated he was in the unit at the time
of the incident. He described seeing Youth A slip into the control
room behind Staff 1 as the door was open. Youth B believed
Youth A was in there for no more than a minute and he ran out of
the control room and then out of the unit. Youth B believed there
were times when the control room doors are left open, and he has
also seen other times when youth have tried to push their way into
the control room.
Youth C was interviewed during a face-to-face, announced visit to
the facility on 07/11/2024. He recalled being present for the
incident in question. Youth C stated he saw Youth A enter the
control room of the unit behind Staff 1 without her knowing it. He
recalled seeing Youth A through the doorway and Youth A was
pressing buttons on a control panel, Youth C believed this to be
controls to automatically locking doors. Youth C stated Youth A
then quickly ran out of the unit and he did not see Youth A after
that time.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone on 07/29/2024. She
recalled the incident in question, stating she and Supervisor 1
were escorting youth back from the gymnasium. She entered the
unit with the youth, recalling hearing the pod door click and lock
behind her, and eventually went into the control room. Staff 1
went into the control room within the unit, and she also recalled
making sure the door clicked and closed behind her. Staff 1
stated she then turned around and was surprised to see Youth A
within the control room. Staff 1 believed Youth A was able to
“pop” the control room door open somehow. She saw him
immediately pressing buttons on a control panel, only for him to
then run out of the control room and out of the unit. Staff 1 stated
she did not follow Youth A in order to stay with the other youth in
the unit, and she radioed for assistance. Staff 1 stated she had
been trained in the past to ensure doors close and lock behind
them when moving about the building, including the control room
of the unit. She confirmed that youth are not allowed in the control
room.
3

Video reviewed:
• Video footage of the 06/29/2024 incident was reviewed. In
the video footage, several youth including Youth A were
seen standing within the unit. Staff 1 entered the control
room, and the door was left open behind her.
Approximately seven seconds later Youth A entered the
control room. The view of inside the control room could not
be seen. Approximately 45 seconds later Youth A could be
seen running out of the control room and then proceeded to
exit the unit on the left side of the footage.
Documents reviewed:
• Two incident reports were provided that document the
incident in question. The first stated Staff 1 helped
transport the youth back to the unit, and then proceeded to
go into the control room. It was written she then left the
door unsecured, with Youth A following her into the control
room. The second incident report contained similar
information to the first.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per video review and
staff and youth interviews, Staff 1 did not secure the door behind
her when entering the control room as she had been trained,
allowing Youth A to gain access to the room.
Consultation provided:
During review of the video footage, it could be seen that another
youth in the unit at the time was able to view inappropriate
material on the television mounted on the wall through a video
game console system. Care should be taken in how youth are
able to use media systems and gain access to inappropriate
material.
Repeat violation established:

Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
